title: Mark's Conundrum with Rotator Cuff Injury
clinical_history: Mark is a 45-year-old avid golfer and office worker. Two months ago, he felt a sharp pain in his right shoulder during a golf swing. The pain has persisted and worsened with certain activities. He experiences a dull ache over the anterolateral shoulder, radiating down the arm to the elbow. He reports weakness in the shoulder when lifting objects overhead or reaching behind him. Night-time discomfort often wakes him up, particularly if he sleeps on his right side.

nprs.affected_area: anterolateral shoulder, radiating down to the elbow

aggrevating_factors: overhead activities, lifting heavy objects, reaching behind the back, prolonged typing or desk work, and golf swings.
picture: [insert image of a person highlighting right shoulder and arm]
easing_factors: rest, ice application, and over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen.
past_history: Mark had a minor shoulder strain eight years ago after a tennis match, which resolved completely. No previous history of shoulder surgeries or significant injuries.
medical_history: Mark has a history of mild hypertension, managed with lifestyle changes, and occasional episodes of acid reflux.
medications: Ibuprofen as needed for pain relief.
personal_history: Mark is married with two teenage children. He maintains an active lifestyle, enjoying golf and jogging. Professionally, he is a marketing manager and spends significant hours working at a computer.
imaging: Ultrasound imaging confirmed a partial tear of the supraspinatus tendon.
